content.description: From the ground just left of the arête edge, follow a crack system heading right for the prominent bulge on the arête. Continuing on cracks, pull past the bulge onto the steep face mid-way up. Now on the arête, work upwards using cracks and face holds to surmount the bulge. Once on the upper face, the angle eases. Use small cracks and edges and head to the top finding a large maple tree to use as an anchor.
content.protection: Gear to 3 inches. Tree anchor at top.
content.location: On the northern end of the east face of Crack Rock

content.description: This low angle face has a plethora of cracks, making it a good choice to work on gear placement. This climb works up a series of cracks along the left-side of the face. There are a few bulges mid-way up that are fun to pull over. Sticking to the crack allows for a wide range of holds including jams, lay-backs, and face holds. Head for the large maple tree on top and use it for a solid anchor.
content.protection: Gear to 3.5 inches. Tree anchor on top.
content.location: Starts in the center of the north face of Crack Rock

content.description:
The first climb done on this face, it took Cadence a long time to get all the moss peeled off to unearth the climb.

From the ground, follow a thin crack leftwards and up into a wide groove. Using holds on both sides of the rough groove, head straight up into the steep crux section. Once through the groove the angle lessens and the holds get bigger and allow an easy finish to a large maple tree anchor on top.
content.location: On northern end of the east face of Crack Rock, just north or large tree.

content.description: This climb follows a series of cracks on the right side of the low angle face. Easy moves on the bottom lead to a prominent bulge on the face, just right of the large bush. Move rightwards past the bulge and continue up cracks to the top where you will find a tree for a solid anchor.
content.protection: Gear to 3.5 inches. Tree anchor on top.
content.location: Starts in the center of the north face of Crack Rock

content.description: From the ground, work up and left on a thin seam. Rough textured rock leads to small crimpers and a steep face at the midway point. Pulling up on the crimpers, find better holds near the top as the angle eases back. Find a large maple tree on top for a solid anchor.
content.location: On the center of the east face of Crack Rock
